question_details.query: Which interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several habitat enhancement interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures. Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundances, with one study finding increased abundance of brown crabs but not other mobile invertebrates, while another reported mixed effects depending on species group (action 3434). Creating short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) had mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance, varying by survey week, species group, flexible habitat length, or site (action 3450). Creating textured surfaces (≤1 mm) produced mixed effects on non-mobile invertebrate abundance depending on the site (action 3449). Creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) resulted in mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance depending on species group and survey week, or flexible habitat length and density, with one study finding decreased mussel abundance on structure surfaces but that the flexible habitats themselves supported higher biomass, mostly mussels (action 3451). Transplanting or seeding organisms showed positive results, with one study finding transplanting sea urchins reduced non-native sea mat cover on kelps, and another reporting that transplanting corals increased coral cover on structure surfaces (action 3471). Creating groove habitats (1-50 mm) had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances depending on species group (action 3448). Creating pit habitats (1-50 mm) also had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances depending on species group (action 3455). Different artificial reef structures and materials showed varying results, with some studies finding no differences in invertebrate abundances between different reef structures and materials, while others found specific materials like oyster shell bags recruited more oysters and ribbed mussels compared to "ReefBall" breakwaters (action 2259). Ceasing or altering maintenance activities showed limited effects on overall abundance but one study found reducing the cleaning area increased seahorse abundance on structure surfaces (action 3447). Creating combinations of grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate abundance depending on surface orientation (action 3452).
summary_statements: Several habitat enhancement interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures.
Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundances.
One study found that creating hole habitats increased the abundance of brown crabs but not other mobile invertebrates.
Another study reported that creating hole habitats had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance depending on the species group.
Creating short flexible habitats between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance.
The effects of short flexible habitats on invertebrate abundance varied by survey week, species group, flexible habitat length, or site.
Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less produced mixed effects on non-mobile invertebrate abundance depending on the site.
Creating long flexible habitats larger than 50 mm resulted in mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance.
The effects of creating long flexible habitats on invertebrate abundance depended on the species group and survey week, or the flexible habitat's length and density.
One study found that creating long flexible habitats decreased mussel abundance on structure surfaces.
The long flexible habitats themselves supported higher biomass, which was mostly comprised of mussels.
Transplanting or seeding organisms showed positive results for invertebrate abundance.
One study found that transplanting sea urchins reduced non-native sea mat cover on kelps.
Another study reported that transplanting corals increased coral cover on structure surfaces.
Creating groove habitats between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances depending on the species group.
Creating pit habitats between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances depending on the species group.
Different artificial reef structures and materials showed varying results for invertebrate abundance.
Some studies found no differences in invertebrate abundances between different reef structures and materials.
Other studies found specific materials like oyster shell bags recruited more oysters and ribbed mussels compared to "ReefBall" breakwaters.
Ceasing or altering maintenance activities showed limited effects on overall invertebrate abundance.
One study found reducing the cleaning area on a structure increased seahorse abundance on its surfaces.
Creating combinations of grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate abundance.
The effects of creating combinations of grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges on abundance depended on the structure's surface orientation.

question_details.query: What are the benefits of creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures for overall species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures provides several benefits for overall species richness. Nine of 12 replicated, controlled studies found that rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species diversity and/or richness than structure surfaces without pools (Action 3476). Rock pools supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools (Action 3476). Combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness in created pools was similar to natural rock pools in some cases (Action 3476). One before-and-after study reported that creating pools, along with reducing the slope of a structure, increased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness on the structure (Action 3476). Rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures were used by sea slugs, urchins, octopuses, macroalgae, invertebrates and fishes (Action 3476). When combined with other habitat features like holes, rock pools supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features and increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces (Action 3467).
summary_statements: Creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures provides several benefits for overall species richness.
Rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species diversity and richness than structure surfaces without pools.
Rock pools supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate, and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools.
The combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness in created pools was similar to natural rock pools in some cases.
Creating pools, along with reducing the slope of a structure, increased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness on the structure.
Rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures were used by sea slugs, urchins, octopuses, macroalgae, invertebrates, and fishes.
When combined with other habitat features like holes, rock pools supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
When combined with other habitat features like holes, rock pools increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and richness on structure surfaces.

question_details.query: What are the general effects on biodiversity of creating linear depressions or elevations on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on multiple studies, creating linear depressions (grooves) and elevations (ridges/ledges) on intertidal artificial structures has varied effects on biodiversity. Linear depressions (groove habitats 1-50mm) show mixed effects on community composition, with two of three studies finding no alteration to combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition, though grooves supported species absent from structure surfaces without grooves (Action 3473). For species richness and diversity, three of six studies found that groove habitats increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity, while two studies found no increase and one had mixed effects depending on site (Action 3473). Grooves supported higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between them in some studies (Action 3473). Linear elevations (small ridges/ledges 1-50mm) generally showed less positive effects, with one of two studies finding no increase in combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness, and studies consistently finding that small ridges supported lower species richness than grooves created between them (Action 3464). Large ridges/ledges (>50mm) showed more positive results, with one of two studies reporting increased combined macroalgae, microalgae and invertebrate species diversity when combined with grooves and small protrusions (Action 3465). When grooves and small ridges/ledges are created together, six of 11 studies found increased species diversity and/or richness, while five studies had mixed effects depending on various factors including depth/height, shore level, and site (Action 3474). For population abundance, effects were similarly mixed, with some studies showing increased abundances while others showed no effect or mixed results depending on the specific organisms and environmental conditions (Actions 3473, 3464, 3465, 3474).
summary_statements: Creating linear depressions (grooves) and elevations (ridges/ledges) on intertidal artificial structures has varied effects on biodiversity.
Linear depressions, such as groove habitats of 1-50mm, show mixed effects on community composition.
Two of three studies found that linear depressions did not alter the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
Grooves supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without grooves.
Some studies found that groove habitats increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity.
Some studies found that groove habitats caused no increase in combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity.
One study found that groove habitats had mixed effects on species richness and/or diversity depending on the site.
Some studies found that grooves supported higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between them.
Linear elevations, such as small ridges or ledges of 1-50mm, generally showed less positive effects on biodiversity than linear depressions.
One study found no increase in combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness from small ridges.
Studies consistently found that small ridges supported lower species richness than grooves created between them.
Large ridges or ledges greater than 50mm showed more positive results for biodiversity than smaller ones.
One study reported that large ridges or ledges, when combined with grooves and small protrusions, increased combined macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrate species diversity.
When grooves and small ridges/ledges are created together, some studies found this increased species diversity and/or richness.
When grooves and small ridges/ledges are created together, some studies found mixed effects on species diversity and/or richness depending on factors like depth, shore level, and site.
The effects of linear depressions and elevations on population abundance were mixed.
Some studies showed increased population abundances due to linear depressions and elevations, while others showed no effect or mixed results.
The effect of linear depressions and elevations on population abundance can depend on the specific organisms and environmental conditions.

question_details.query: Which interventions are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from multiple studies, the most consistently effective interventions for altering overall community composition on subtidal artificial structures are: 1) Using environmentally-sensitive materials: Six of 11 studies found that using shell-concrete or quarried rock in place of standard-concrete, or using ECOncrete™ in place of standard-concrete or fibreglass, along with creating texture, grooves, holes, pits and/or small ledges, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces (Action ID 3470). Three studies also reported that ECOncrete™ surfaces with added habitats supported mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from standard-concrete or fibreglass structure surfaces. 2) Creating hole habitats (>50 mm): All three studies found that creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures, along with grooves, environmentally-sensitive material and pits or small ledges in two studies, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate or mobile invertebrate and fish community composition on and around structures (Action ID 3434). They also supported mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features. 3) Creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm): Both studies found that long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate or fish species that were absent from on and around structure surfaces without flexible habitats (Action ID 3451). 4) Creating grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges: One of two studies found that groove habitats and small ledges created on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition and supported non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features (Action ID 3452). Less consistently effective interventions included creating textured surfaces (2 of 3 studies showed effects on community composition), creating groove habitats alone, creating pit habitats, and creating short flexible habitats. Harvesting restrictions showed effects on fish community composition but had limited evidence. Ceasing or altering maintenance activities showed minimal effects on community composition (Action ID 3447).
summary_statements: Using shell-concrete or quarried rock in place of standard-concrete alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
Using ECOncrete™ in place of standard-concrete or fibreglass alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.

Creating texture, grooves, holes, pits and/or small ledges in addition to using environmentally-sensitive materials alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
ECOncrete™ surfaces with added habitats support mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that are absent from standard-concrete or fibreglass structure surfaces.
Creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate or mobile invertebrate and fish community composition on and around the structures.

Creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures also supports mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that are absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
Long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures support macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate or fish species that are absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.

Groove habitats and small ledges created on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, alter the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.

Groove habitats and small ledges created on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, support non-mobile invertebrate species that are absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
Creating textured surfaces is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
Creating groove habitats alone is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
Creating pit habitats is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
Creating short flexible habitats is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
Harvesting restrictions show effects on fish community composition but have limited evidence.
Ceasing or altering maintenance activities show minimal effects on community composition.

question_details.query: For intertidal artificial structures in Australia, which habitat modifications have shown mixed or neutral results for fish abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several habitat modifications on intertidal artificial structures in Australia have shown mixed or neutral results for fish abundance:

Creating short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) showed neutral results for fish abundance, as one study found it did not increase fish abundance on and around structure surfaces during high tide (action 3459).

Creating rock pools demonstrated mixed effects on fish abundance, with one Australian study finding mixed effects depending on the species group and site (action 3476).

Transplanting or seeding organisms onto structures showed neutral results, with two Australian studies finding that transplanting oysters and/or coralline algae did not increase fish abundance on and around structure surfaces (action 3472).

Creating grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1-50 mm) showed neutral results, with three Australian studies finding these modifications did not increase combined fish or juvenile salmon abundances on and around structure surfaces (action 3474).

Creating small ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) showed neutral results, with one Australian study finding that small ledges supported similar fish abundance to grooves created in between them (action 3464).
summary_statements: Several habitat modifications on intertidal artificial structures in Australia have shown mixed or neutral results for fish abundance.
Creating short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) showed neutral results for fish abundance.
One study found that creating short flexible habitats did not increase fish abundance on and around structure surfaces during high tide.
Creating rock pools demonstrated mixed effects on fish abundance.
One Australian study on creating rock pools found mixed effects on fish abundance depending on the species group and site.
Transplanting or seeding organisms onto structures showed neutral results for fish abundance.
Two Australian studies found that transplanting oysters and/or coralline algae did not increase fish abundance on and around structure surfaces.
Creating grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1-50 mm) showed neutral results for fish abundance.
Three Australian studies found that creating grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges did not increase combined fish or juvenile salmon abundances on and around structure surfaces.
Creating small ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) showed neutral results for fish abundance.
One Australian study found that small ledges supported similar fish abundance to grooves created in between the ledges.

question_details.query: Which interventions have been shown to benefit fish populations on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents reviewed, several interventions have been shown to benefit fish populations on subtidal artificial structures:

Harvesting restrictions (action 3457): One site comparison study in Italy found that harvesting restrictions on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from unrestricted structures and resulted in higher fish species richness compared with unrestricted structures. One study found higher seabream abundances around structures with harvesting restrictions.

Creating long flexible habitats (action 3451): Studies in Australia and the Netherlands found that long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats. Two randomized controlled studies found mixed effects on fish abundance depending on the species and fish presence when flexible habitats were created, or the survey week.

Creating large swimthrough habitats (action 3456): One replicated, paired sites, controlled study in the USA found that creating large swimthrough habitats in front of a subtidal artificial structure increased overall fish species richness and abundance on and around structure surfaces, though effects varied depending on fish size class, species, and survey month. The swimthrough habitats supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without swimthroughs.

Creating hole habitats (action 3434): Three replicated, controlled studies in Israel and Sweden found that creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features. However, studies found mixed effects on fish abundances depending on the species group, with one study reporting no increase in fish species abundances.

Transplanting organisms (action 3471): One replicated, paired sites, controlled study in the USA found that transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures altered fish community composition and increased combined invertebrate and fish species richness and diversity on and around structure surfaces.

Creating pit habitats (action 3455): One replicated, controlled study in Israel found that pit habitats created on a subtidal artificial structure supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without the added habitat features, though effects on fish abundances varied depending on the species group.
summary_statements: Several interventions have been shown to benefit fish populations on subtidal artificial structures.
Harvesting restrictions on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from unrestricted structures.
Harvesting restrictions on subtidal artificial structures resulted in higher fish species richness compared with unrestricted structures.
Higher seabream abundances were found around structures with harvesting restrictions.
Long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.
The creation of long flexible habitats had mixed effects on fish abundance depending on the species, fish presence when the habitats were created, or the survey week.
Creating large swimthrough habitats in front of a subtidal artificial structure increased overall fish species richness and abundance on and around structure surfaces.
The effects of large swimthrough habitats varied depending on fish size class, species, and survey month.
The swimthrough habitats supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without swimthroughs.
Creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
Creating hole habitats had mixed effects on fish abundances depending on the species group.
In one case, creating hole habitats resulted in no increase in fish species abundances.
Transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures altered fish community composition.
Transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures increased combined invertebrate and fish species richness and diversity on and around structure surfaces.
Pit habitats created on a subtidal artificial structure supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without the added habitat features.
The effects of pit habitats on fish abundances varied depending on the species group.

question_details.query: What conservation actions for artificial structures have been studied in estuaries in Australia, and what were the outcomes?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Multiple conservation actions for artificial structures have been studied in Australian estuaries, focusing on habitat enhancement and organism transplantation approaches. Creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures has been examined in three studies in southeast Australian estuaries, with outcomes showing that these habitats supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats (action 3451). The long flexible habitats were found to be used by seahorses and had mixed effects on fish species richness and abundance around structures, depending on fish presence when habitats were created (action 3451).

Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures was studied in three Australian estuarine sites, demonstrating that holes (along with rock pools) supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate species absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features, and increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and richness (action 3467). These hole habitats were observed being used by sea slugs, urchins and octopuses, though they had mixed effects on limpet abundance depending on shore level and site (action 3467).

Creating groove habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures has been extensively studied with seven studies conducted in southeast Australian estuaries. The outcomes showed that grooves supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without grooves, and grooves supported higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between them (action 3473). However, grooves did not consistently increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition or abundance on structure surfaces (action 3473).

Transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures was examined in seven Australian estuarine studies, with outcomes showing that transplanted oysters supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without transplanted oysters (action 3472). Transplanting oysters had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity, depending on site and presence of grooves and small ridges on surfaces, and increased mobile invertebrate species richness (action 3472).

Creating short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures was studied in one Australian estuarine site, with outcomes showing altered combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition, but decreased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness during low tide (action 3459).

Using environmentally-sensitive materials on both intertidal and subtidal artificial structures has been studied in Australian estuaries, with outcomes showing that sandstone in place of basalt had mixed effects on community composition depending on site, while reduced-pH-concrete surfaces supported species absent from standard-concrete surfaces (action 3469, 3470).

Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures was examined in Australian estuarine studies, with outcomes showing that slope reduction (along with creating rock pools) increased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness, but did not increase macroalgal, oyster or mobile invertebrate abundance (action 3461).

Transplanting organisms onto subtidal artificial structures was studied in one Australian estuarine site, with outcomes showing that transplanting sea urchins reduced cover of non-native sea mat on kelps growing on the structure (action 3471).
summary_statements: Multiple conservation actions for artificial structures have been studied in Australian estuaries.
The conservation actions studied in Australian estuaries focused on habitat enhancement and organism transplantation approaches.
Creating long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures has been examined in three studies in southeast Australian estuaries.
Long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.
The long flexible habitats were found to be used by seahorses.
Long flexible habitats had mixed effects on fish species richness and abundance around structures, depending on fish presence when the habitats were created.
Creating hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures was studied in three Australian estuarine sites.
Hole habitats supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate species absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
Hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and richness.
Hole habitats were observed being used by sea slugs, urchins and octopuses.
Hole habitats had mixed effects on limpet abundance depending on shore level and site.
Creating groove habitats on intertidal artificial structures has been extensively studied with seven studies conducted in southeast Australian estuaries.
Grooves on intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without grooves.
Grooves supported higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between the grooves.
Grooves did not consistently increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition or abundance on structure surfaces.
Transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures was examined in seven Australian estuarine studies.

Transplanted oysters on intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without transplanted oysters.
Transplanting oysters had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity, depending on site and presence of grooves and small ridges on surfaces.
Transplanting oysters increased mobile invertebrate species richness.
Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures was studied in one Australian estuarine site.
Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition.
Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures decreased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness during low tide.
Using environmentally-sensitive materials on both intertidal and subtidal artificial structures has been studied in Australian estuaries.
Using sandstone in place of basalt on artificial structures had mixed effects on community composition depending on site.
Reduced-pH-concrete surfaces on artificial structures supported species absent from standard-concrete surfaces.
Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures was examined in Australian estuarine studies.
Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures increased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness.
Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures did not increase macroalgal, oyster or mobile invertebrate abundance.
Transplanting organisms onto subtidal artificial structures was studied in one Australian estuarine site.
Transplanting sea urchins onto subtidal artificial structures reduced the cover of non-native sea mat on kelps growing on the structure.

question_details.query: What are the general effects of creating linear habitat features, such as grooves, ridges or ledges, on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Creating linear habitat features such as grooves, ridges or ledges on intertidal artificial structures produces varied effects on biodiversity. Community composition studies show that creating groove habitats and small ridges/ledges can alter combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition, with effects depending on site-specific factors, the presence of water-retaining and light-shading covers, and the size and arrangement of features (Action 3474). Multiple studies found that these linear features support species that were absent from structure surfaces without grooves and ridges/ledges (Action 3474).

For species richness and diversity, six of 11 studies found that creating groove habitats and small ridges/ledges increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces (Action 3474). However, effects varied depending on depth/height of grooves and ridges, shore level, species group and site (Action 3474). Comparative studies found that grooves supported higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created in between them, though species diversity in grooves versus ridges varied depending on groove depth (Action 3473).

Population abundance responses were mixed across studies. Two of six studies found that creating groove habitats and small ridges/ledges did not increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance, while two found increases when features were partially-covered with water-retaining and light-shading covers or combined with large ledges (Action 3474). For invertebrates specifically, five of seven studies found mixed effects on mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate, limpet, mussel, juvenile oyster and barnacle abundances, depending on feature depth/height, presence of large ledges or covers, shore level, and site (Action 3474).

Fish responses showed that creating groove habitats and small ridges/ledges generally did not increase fish species richness or abundance, with two of three studies finding no increase in fish species richness (Action 3474). However, behavioral effects included increased feeding activity for juvenile salmon and increased time benthic fishes spent interacting with structure surfaces (Action 3474). Large ridges or ledges (>50 mm) showed different patterns, with studies finding increased abundance of mussels or limpets but not barnacles, and increased rockweed abundance (Action 3465).

Groove habitats specifically were found to be colonized by microalgal species and were used by mussels and periwinkles (Actions 3474, 3473). The effectiveness of linear habitat features appears to depend heavily on design parameters including size, arrangement, depth, and the presence of additional features or covers.
summary_statements: Creating linear habitat features such as grooves, ridges or ledges on intertidal artificial structures produces varied effects on biodiversity.
Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges can alter the combined community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates.

The effects of groove habitats and small ridges or ledges on community composition depend on site-specific factors, the presence of water-retaining and light-shading covers, and the size and arrangement of the features.
Linear features like grooves, ridges, and ledges support species that are absent from artificial structure surfaces that lack these features.
Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges on structure surfaces has been found to increase the combined species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.
The effects of grooves and ridges on species richness and diversity vary depending on the depth or height of the features, the shore level, the species group, and the site.
Grooves on artificial structures support higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between the grooves.
Species diversity in grooves versus ridges varies depending on the depth of the groove.
The responses of population abundance to the creation of linear habitat features were mixed across studies.
Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges did not always increase the combined abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates.
The abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates increased when linear features were partially-covered with water-retaining and light-shading covers.
The abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates increased when linear features were combined with large ledges.
The creation of linear habitat features had mixed effects on the abundances of mobile invertebrates, non-mobile invertebrates, limpets, mussels, juvenile oysters, and barnacles.
The effects of linear habitat features on invertebrate abundances depended on the feature's depth or height, the presence of large ledges or covers, the shore level, and the site.
Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges generally does not increase fish species richness or abundance.
Behavioral effects of creating linear features on intertidal artificial structures included increased feeding activity for juvenile salmon.
Behavioral effects of creating linear features on intertidal artificial structures included an increased amount of time that benthic fishes spent interacting with structure surfaces.
Large ridges or ledges greater than 50 mm in size led to an increased abundance of mussels and limpets, but not barnacles.
Large ridges or ledges greater than 50 mm in size led to increased rockweed abundance.
Groove habitats on intertidal artificial structures were found to be colonized by microalgal species.
Groove habitats on intertidal artificial structures were used by mussels and periwinkles.
The effectiveness of linear habitat features appears to depend heavily on design parameters including the size, arrangement, and depth of the features.
The effectiveness of linear habitat features appears to depend heavily on the presence of additional features or covers.

question_details.query: Which habitat creation methods appear most consistently effective at increasing overall species richness on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The most consistently effective habitat creation methods for increasing species richness on subtidal artificial structures are combinations of multiple small-scale features and the use of ECOncrete materials. Action 3434 found that creating hole habitats (>50 mm) along with grooves, environmentally-sensitive material and pits or small ledges increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on and around structures in two of three studies conducted in Israel and Sweden. Action 3452 demonstrated that creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on structure surfaces in one of two studies in Israel and the UK. Action 3448 showed that groove habitats (1-50 mm) created along with holes, pits and environmentally-sensitive material increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity in Israel. Action 3455 found that pit habitats (1-50 mm) created with holes, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity on structure surfaces in Israel. Action 3456 demonstrated that large adjoining cavities or swimthrough habitats (>100 mm) increased overall fish species richness on and around structure surfaces in the USA. Action 3470 showed that using ECOncrete material along with creating texture, grooves, holes, pits and/or small ledges increased species diversity and/or richness on and around structures in three studies across multiple locations. Action 3471 found that transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures increased combined invertebrate and fish species richness and diversity on and around structure surfaces in the USA. The evidence indicates that combinations of multiple habitat features rather than single features, and the use of specialized materials like ECOncrete, appear most consistently effective at enhancing species richness.
summary_statements: The most consistently effective habitat creation methods for increasing species richness on subtidal artificial structures are combinations of multiple small-scale features.
The use of ECOncrete materials is one of the most consistently effective habitat creation methods for increasing species richness on subtidal artificial structures.

Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm, along with grooves, environmentally-sensitive material, and pits or small ledges, increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on and around structures.

Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm), along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on structure surfaces.
Groove habitats (1-50 mm) created along with holes, pits, and environmentally-sensitive material increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity.
Pit habitats (1-50 mm) created with holes, grooves, and environmentally-sensitive material increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity on structure surfaces.
Large adjoining cavities or swim-through habitats larger than 100 mm increased overall fish species richness on and around structure surfaces.
Using ECOncrete material along with creating texture, grooves, holes, pits and/or small ledges increased species diversity and/or richness on and around structures.
Transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures increased combined invertebrate and fish species richness and diversity on and around structure surfaces.
Evidence indicates that combinations of multiple habitat features appear more consistently effective at enhancing species richness than single features.
The use of specialized materials like ECOncrete appears most consistently effective at enhancing species richness.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures by creating crevices, protrusions, ridges, ledges, or by reducing their slope?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures through structural modifications is mixed and limited. For grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm), three studies from marinas in northern Israel and the UK and an open coastline in southeast Spain showed that these features can alter community composition and support non-mobile invertebrate species absent from unmodified surfaces (Action 3452). One study found that groove habitats and small ledges increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity, while another found mixed effects depending on surface orientation (Action 3452). 

For groove habitats alone (1-50 mm), two studies from Japan and northern Israel found they can alter community composition and increase species diversity when combined with other features like holes and pits (Action 3448). These grooves supported macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species absent from structures without habitat features (Action 3448).

For hole habitats (>50 mm), three studies from Israel and Sweden found they altered community composition and supported species absent from unmodified structures (Action 3434). Two of three studies found holes increased species richness and/or diversity when combined with other structural features (Action 3434). One study found holes increased brown crab abundance but had mixed effects on other species groups (Action 3434).

For pit habitats (1-50 mm), one study from Israel found they altered community composition and increased species diversity when combined with holes, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material (Action 3455). Effects on abundances were mixed depending on species group (Action 3455).

However, no studies were found evaluating the effects of creating large ridges or ledges (>50 mm), crevice habitats (>50 mm), or reducing the slope of subtidal artificial structures, meaning there is no evidence for these specific interventions (Actions 3445, 3454, 3442).
summary_statements: The evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures through structural modifications is mixed and limited.
Grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges measuring 1-50 mm can alter community composition.
Grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges measuring 1-50 mm can support non-mobile invertebrate species absent from unmodified surfaces.
Groove habitats and small ledges have been found to increase the combined species richness and diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates.
The effects of groove habitats and small ledges can be mixed depending on surface orientation.
Groove habitats measuring 1-50 mm can alter community composition and increase species diversity when combined with other features like holes and pits.
Groove habitats supported macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species that were absent from structures without habitat features.
Hole habitats larger than 50 mm altered community composition and supported species absent from unmodified structures.
Holes on subtidal artificial structures increased species richness and/or diversity when combined with other structural features.
Holes on subtidal artificial structures increased brown crab abundance.
Holes on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on other species groups.
Pit habitats measuring 1-50 mm altered community composition and increased species diversity when combined with holes, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material.
The effects of pit habitats on the abundances of different species groups were mixed.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of creating large ridges or ledges greater than 50 mm on subtidal artificial structures.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of creating crevice habitats greater than 50 mm on subtidal artificial structures.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of reducing the slope of subtidal artificial structures.

question_details.query: Which habitat creation methods are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Rock pools are the most consistently effective habitat creation method for altering overall community composition on intertidal artificial structures. Sixteen replicated, controlled studies found that rock pools supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools (Action 3476). Additionally, rock pools created different combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition compared to surfaces without pools (Action 3476).

Pit habitats (1–50 mm) also demonstrate consistent effectiveness, with four of six replicated, controlled studies finding that pit habitats altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces (Action 3475). Nine studies reported that pit habitats supported macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitats (Action 3475).

Hole habitats (>50 mm) showed consistent community composition effects, with three studies finding that hole habitats altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces and supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features (Action 3467).

Long flexible habitats (>50 mm) altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces and supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats (Action 3460).

In contrast, groove habitats (1–50 mm) showed mixed results, with two of three studies finding that groove habitats did not alter the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces (Action 3473). Similarly, small ridges or ledges (1–50 mm) showed inconsistent effects, with one of two studies finding no alteration to community composition (Action 3464).
summary_statements: Rock pools are the most consistently effective habitat creation method for altering overall community composition on intertidal artificial structures.
Rock pools supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate, and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools.
Rock pools created a different combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition compared to surfaces without pools.
Pit habitats demonstrate consistent effectiveness in altering the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
Pit habitats supported macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitats.
Hole habitats altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
Hole habitats supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
Long flexible habitats altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
Long flexible habitats supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.
Groove habitats showed mixed results for altering the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
Small ridges or ledges showed inconsistent effects on altering community composition.

question_details.query: What are the potential negative impacts or limitations of adding topographical complexity to enhance biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents reviewed, several limitations and mixed results have been identified regarding adding topographical complexity to enhance biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures. Creating natural rocky reef topography did not increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness on structure surfaces and had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances depending on the site (Action 3435). Creating pit habitats showed variable effectiveness, with studies finding that pit creation did not alter community composition in some cases, did not increase species richness in some studies, and decreased combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance in one study (Action 3475). The effects of pit habitats were frequently site-dependent and varied based on pit size and arrangement. Creating textured surfaces had mixed effects on species richness depending on the type of texture created and the site, and some studies found no increase in macroalgal or invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces (Action 3466). Reducing slope showed limited benefits, with one study finding no increase in macroalgal abundance or oyster and mobile invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces (Action 3461). Creating hole habitats showed some limitations, with studies reporting no increase in macroalgal abundance and mixed effects on limpet abundance depending on shore level and site (Action 3467). The effectiveness of topographical complexity modifications appears to be highly context-dependent, with results varying significantly based on site conditions, specific design parameters, and target species.
summary_statements: Several limitations and mixed results have been identified regarding adding topographical complexity to enhance biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures.
Creating natural rocky reef topography did not increase the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates on structure surfaces.
Creating natural rocky reef topography had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances, with outcomes depending on the site.
Creating pit habitats has shown variable effectiveness in enhancing biodiversity.
Studies have found that pit creation did not alter community composition in some cases.
Some studies found that pit creation did not increase species richness.
One study found that creating pit habitats decreased the combined abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates.
The effects of pit habitats were frequently site-dependent.
The effects of pit habitats varied based on the size and arrangement of the pits.
Creating textured surfaces had mixed effects on species richness, depending on the type of texture and the site.
Some studies found no increase in macroalgal or invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces with created textures.
Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures showed limited benefits for biodiversity.
One study found that reducing the slope of a structure did not increase macroalgal abundance or the abundance of oysters and mobile invertebrates.
Creating hole habitats showed some limitations for enhancing biodiversity.
Studies reported no increase in macroalgal abundance from the creation of hole habitats.
Creating hole habitats had mixed effects on limpet abundance, depending on the shore level and site.
The effectiveness of topographical complexity modifications appears to be highly context-dependent.
Results of adding topographical complexity vary significantly based on site conditions, specific design parameters, and target species.

question_details.query: Besides choosing different construction materials, what other interventions can modify the surface of artificial structures to benefit biodiversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several surface modification interventions can be applied to artificial structures to benefit biodiversity beyond material choice. Creating textured surfaces (≤1 mm) on artificial structures can alter community composition on structure surfaces, with studies showing changes in macroalgae and invertebrate communities and support for species absent from non-textured surfaces (Action ID 3449, 3466). Small protrusions (1-50 mm) can be added to artificial structures, which have shown mixed effects on macroalgal abundance depending on species (Action ID 3453). Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) together on artificial structures can alter community composition and increase species richness and diversity, supporting species absent from structures without these features (Action ID 3452). Short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) can be installed on structures to alter community composition (Action ID 3459). The slope of artificial structures can be reduced to increase species richness when combined with other modifications like creating rock pools (Action ID 3461). Groove habitats (1-50 mm) can be created on structures to alter community composition and increase species diversity, supporting species groups not found on unmodified structures (Action ID 3448). Pit habitats (1-50 mm) can be created on artificial structures to alter community composition and increase species diversity (Action ID 3455). Natural rocky reef topography can be created on structures, though effects on biodiversity vary (Action ID 3446). Organisms can be transplanted or seeded onto artificial structures to alter community composition and increase species richness and diversity (Action ID 3471). Green infrastructure including green roofs can be established in urban areas, though they may have lower species richness compared to urban parks (Action ID 3837). Textured coatings can be applied to specific structures like turbines, though effects on wildlife activity may be limited (Action ID 1957).
summary_statements: Several surface modification interventions can be applied to artificial structures to benefit biodiversity beyond material choice.
Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on artificial structures can alter the community composition on the surfaces of those structures.
Studies have shown that textured surfaces can cause changes in macroalgae and invertebrate communities and support species absent from non-textured surfaces.
Adding small protrusions of 1-50 mm to artificial structures has shown mixed effects on macroalgal abundance, with results depending on the species.
Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges of 1-50 mm together on artificial structures can alter community composition and increase species richness and diversity.
The addition of grooves, protrusions, ridges, or ledges to artificial structures can support species absent from structures without these features.
Short flexible habitats of 1-50 mm can be installed on structures to alter community composition.
Reducing the slope of artificial structures can increase species richness when combined with other modifications like creating rock pools.
Creating groove habitats of 1-50 mm on structures can alter community composition and increase species diversity.
Groove habitats on structures can support species groups that are not found on unmodified structures.
Creating pit habitats of 1-50 mm on artificial structures can alter community composition and increase species diversity.
Natural rocky reef topography can be created on structures, though the effects on biodiversity vary.
Organisms can be transplanted or seeded onto artificial structures to alter community composition and increase species richness and diversity.
Green infrastructure, including green roofs, can be established in urban areas.
Green infrastructure may have lower species richness compared to urban parks.
Applying textured coatings to specific structures like turbines may have limited effects on wildlife activity.
